column1: Moreno Valley is a city in Riverside County
column2: California
column3: and is part of the Riverside-San Bernardino-Ontario Metropolitan Area. A relatively young city
column4: its rapid growth from the late 1980s to the early 2000s made it the second-largest city in Riverside County by population
column5: and one of the Inland Empire's population centers. As of the 2010 census
column7: 365. The city is closely tied to Riverside
column9: the county seat and largest city in the county
column10: which borders Moreno Valley directly to the west. Moreno Valley is also part of the Greater Los Angeles area.

column1: The city derived its name from the small community of Moreno
column2: which became part of the city of Moreno Valley when the city was incorporated in 1984. Frank E. Brown
column3: one of the founders of Moreno in 1882
column4: declined to have the town named after him
column5: so to honor him instead

column1: The Moreno Valley area was first inhabited 2
column2: 300 years ago. There are at least 200 prehistoric archaeological locations within the city. The majority of the sites are milling stations - where chaparral seed was the dominant milling activity. Rock art
column3: consisting of pictographs
column4: and petroglyphs are present - though most of the petroglyphs in Moreno Valley consist of boulders with "cupules"
column5: or cup-shaped holes pecked into them.Spanish scouts initially came across descendants of the Shoshone
column6: and Luiseño tribes; although other groups
column7: such as the Serrano and Cahuilla were in the area. The late prehistoric Luiseño and Cahuilla were semi-sedentary
column8: meaning that they wintered in villages
column9: then spread out in family groups during the spring and summer months to harvest seeds and acorns.Spanish scouts blazed a number of trails in the area
column11: which runs through the Edgemont area of present-day Moreno Valley.

column1: When California was admitted to the United States as a state in 1850
column2: Americans began to move into the area. The Tucson-to-San Francisco route of John Butterfield's Overland Mail Company passed through it. Some farmers began to occupy the area
column3: relying upon water from Frank E. Brown's Bear Valley Land and Water Company. Beginning in 1883
column4: the company collected and pumped water from Bear Valley
column5: California in the San Bernardino Mountains to the north. The area first acquired its current name
column8: referring to Frank Brown (moreno is Spanish for "brown" or "brunet"). In 1899
column9: the city of Redlands won a lawsuit in which the city claimed eminent domain over the Bear Valley water. The resulting loss of service forced most of the area's inhabitants to move.

column1: The revival of the Moreno Valley area began in 1918
column2: when the United States Air Force (then the United States Army Air Service) constructed March Field on the outskirts of Riverside as part of its World War I expansion. March Field was initially used to train fighter pilots. Although it was closed in 1922
column3: it was reopened in 1927 and eventually became a full Air Force base. The presence of March caused the unincorporated communities of Sunnymead
column4: Moreno
column5: and Edgemont to develop and grow. In World War II
column6: March again became a training ground for military pilots. On April 1
column8: March Air Force Base (MAFB) became March Joint Air Reserve Base (MJARB) under Air Force Reserve Command (AFRC).

column2: the Riverside International Raceway occupied the current site of the Moreno Valley Mall. The Riverside International Raceway (sometimes known as RIR or Riverside Raceway) race track was in operation from September 22
column4: to July 3
column5: 1989. Races held at the Riverside International Raceway included IMSA

column1: The area experienced explosive growth in the 1980s. By 1984
column2: the population was 49
column3: 702 (compared to 18
column4: 871 residents in 1970). The state economic boom fueled the construction of new houses and businesses
column5: leading to a push for incorporation. Although similar measures had failed in 1968 and 1983
column6: a measure to form the city of Moreno Valley was approved by voters in 1984. On December 3
column10: and Moreno united with nearby areas to form the general law city of Moreno Valley. The first City Council was also elected in 1984
column14: J. David Horspool (first Mayor Pro Tem)
column15: and Marshall C. Scott (first Mayor). The City Seal and Motto were adopted the following year.

column2: Moreno Valley had exploded in population growth to become the second-largest city in Riverside County with a population of over 118
column3: 000. This growth continued until about 1992.

column2: the robust Moreno Valley economy deteriorated
column3: largely due to the statewide economic downturn. Many people began to leave the city. March was also downsized to its present status as March Air Reserve Base. The surplus land was given to the March Joint Powers Authority
column4: made up of representatives of Riverside County and the cities of Riverside
column5: Moreno Valley
column6: and Perris for development. The dismal economic trend began to reverse in the late part of the decade
column7: however. Companies such as Aurora Modular
column9: and Lowe's moved major operating facilities to the city or neighboring municipalities (although Aurora later filed for bankruptcy).

column2: the arrival of many newcomers to Riverside County and the soaring cost of living in Los Angeles and Orange County combined to make the less-developed southern half of the Inland Empire an attractive place for industry.

column1: On the east end of the city off Moreno Beach Drive
column2: a new Walmart was opened in early 2006 next to the Moreno Valley Auto Mall. This is also the site of the first Super Target in California and the first Best Buy store located within Moreno Valley city limits
column3: which opened in July and October 2007
column4: respectively. The exit off State Route 60 is the main way to the Moreno Valley Ranch Golf Course
column5: once included in Golf Magazine's Top 75 Golf Courses in the USA.

column1: Proposals to turn March Joint Air Reserve Base to a major commercial airport were debated in 2005
column2: but the plan was rejected by the Riverside county board of supervisors. However
column3: the coming of quieter
column4: more environmentally friendly aircraft and cheaper security procedures and utilities may signal a re-consideration of the plan. In May 2008 the March JPA approved opening the facility to general aircraft.

column1: DHL selected March Air Reserve Base as its Southern California hub and commenced operations in October 2005.  While initial claims were that the facility would employ 250 workers in its initial stage
column2: over 300 employees went to work daily during normal operations. In November 2008
column3: DHL announced it was leaving the U.S. market and would shut its operation associated with March Air Field in January 2009.March Air Reserve base has a ball park facility
column4: where the semi-pro baseball Inland Empire (now Rancho Belago) Rockets of the Southern California League play in the summer months season.

column3: the City Council passed
column4: by a vote of 4–1
column5: a controversial resolution christening the eastern half of the city (roughly from Lasselle Street to Gilman Springs Road) "Rancho Belago"
column6: a pastiche of Spanish and Italian words. The city council's resolution includes the 92555 ZIP Code within the boundaries of the area
column7: as reported by the Press Enterprise newspaper.

column2: Moreno Valley is home to around 210
column3: 000 residents and once again
column4: experienced an economic bust (the late 2000s recession) to restart again in a new development boom. Metrolink rail transit has arrived in the area as far south as Perris
column5: and a proposal to erect a four-lane freeway (known as Mid County Parkway) near the site of Cajalco Road/Ramona Expressway from Interstate 215 to State Route 79 in San Jacinto is currently being studied by Caltrans as well as Riverside County. Upper-middle class residents reside in newer housing developments on the eastern half of the city. Recent years have seen the rise of corporate office industrial and business parks
column6: as well a proposal of bringing minor league baseball of the California League to town.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 51.5 square miles (133 km2)
column3: of which
column4: 51.3 square miles (133 km2) of it is land and 0.2 square miles (0.52 km2) of it is water.

column1: Moreno Valley is located at a geographic crossroad. To the east lies the San Gorgonio Pass and Coachella Valley; to the south are Lake Perris
column2: Perris
column3: and the San Jacinto Mountains; to the north are the San Bernardino Valley and San Bernardino Mountains. To the west lies neighboring Riverside. It is relatively close to Ontario International Airport.

column1: One of the most visible geographical features in Moreno Valley
column2: visible from almost anywhere in the city
column3: is Box Springs Mountain. This mountain at the northwest end of the city towers over the city
column4: providing a concrete landmark. The face of the mountain that faces the city has a large "M" constructed upon it. This was built privately at the encouragement of the City Council
column5: which argued it would foster unity. The letter is located on public land and is maintained entirely by charity. The letter had lights installed on December 3
column6: 2005 to celebrate Moreno Valley's 21st anniversary of its incorporation and the completion of the repairs of heavy damage to the M
column7: due to excessive rain the year before. The mayor at that time
column9: has said that the citizens liked it that way and that the council would try to get it to light up regularly. Between December 2
column13: along with Edison lit up the "M" in celebration of the city's 25th anniversary. Several Eagle Scout projects have been dedicated to maintaining the letter.

column1: Moreno Valley has a mild semi-arid climate (Köppen BSh)
column2: with Mediterranean characteristics. The summer temperatures average in the high 90s
column3: though many days reach well above 100°.

column2: the warmest month is August.

column1: The highest recorded temperature was 118 °F (48 °C) in July 2018.

column2: the coolest month is December.

column1: The lowest recorded temperature was 22 °F (−6 °C) in 1974.
The maximum average precipitation occurs in December.

column1: Moreno Valley incorporated in 1984 as a general law city. It currently uses the council-manager form of government. The city is divided into four council districts
column2: each of which elect a representative to the city council. The mayor is directly elected at-large. The council chooses one of its members to serve as Mayor Pro Tem. The council also selects the city manager
column3: the city attorney
column4: and city clerk.

column1: Moreno Valley is served by its own regional station of the Riverside County Sheriff's Department for law enforcement. The sheriff's station is currently commanded by Sheriff's Captain Joel Ontiveros
column2: who also functions as Moreno Valley's Chief of Police.

column1: The city of Moreno Valley contracts for fire and paramedic services with the Riverside County Fire Department through a cooperative agreement with CAL FIRE. 7 paramedic engines and a truck company provide both fire and paramedic services to the city.
American Medical Response is responsible for transports to emergency departments via paramedic ambulance.
Moreno Valley's primary and secondary education needs are fulfilled by the Moreno Valley Unified School District and the Val Verde Unified School District. The former serves approximately 35
column2: 000 students
column3: the bulk of the city's children
column4: and has 35 schools
column5: including five high schools: Moreno Valley High School
column9: and Vista del Lago High School. Val Verde District serves part of southern and eastern Moreno Valley
column10: in addition to parts of Perris
column12: and unincorporated areas. It serves about 13
column13: 000 students and maintains 12 schools; one of its high schools
column15: is located in Moreno Valley. Some private schools exist
column16: including the local Valley Christian Academy
column19: which serves students Kindergarten to twelfth grade. There is also growing number of charter schools within Moreno Valley area including Excel Prep Charter School – Inland Empire
column23: a 6–12 independent study program.The Riverside Community College District
column26: 500 students at their Moreno Valley College campus. The city is also the location of one of the twenty-six Chapman University campuses. In neighboring Riverside
column27: students may opt to attend RCCD's main campus
column31: La Sierra University or California Baptist University. California State University
column32: San Bernardino is another popular school for city high school graduates.

column1: Moreno Valley has two public libraries.
The heavily traveled routes of State Route 60 (locally called the Moreno Valley Freeway) and Interstate 215 both pass through the city.
The Moreno Valley/March Field station of the Metrolink commuter rail system
column2: located just west of the city limits
column3: opened in June 2016. Monday through Friday service is provided on the 91 Line connecting the Moreno Valley area with Riverside and Downtown Los Angeles to the north and Perris to the south. The Riverside Transit Agency provides local and express/commuter bus services.

column1: There are two hospitals in Moreno Valley:

column2: formerly Moreno Valley Community Hospital
column3: is a General Acute Care Hospital with Basic Emergency Services as of 2008. Kaiser Permanente officially acquired the Moreno Valley Community Hospital and took complete control in July 2008. Current Kaiser Permanente members began receiving notification of the purchase in March 2008. Moreno Valley residents will not feel the effects of the acquisition immediately
column4: as Kaiser Permanente members were asked to continue using the nearby Riverside facility and the Moreno Valley Clinic for hospital services while the transition process is completed. Kaiser Permanente is planning to increase the size and capacity of the new hospital by adding a new 80+ patient tower and expanding the main facility
column5: as well as increasing the size of the emergency and operating rooms.

column1: Riverside County Regional Medical Center is a General Acute Care Hospital with Basic Emergency Services and a Level II Trauma Center.
